overview:
Tim is the HR Director at Logistics UK and has extensive prior experience
working with large executive search firms, including Korn Ferry, across
multiple organisations and roles. In the most recent engagement, Korn
Ferry was appointed following a competitive process to support a senior
executive search.
Tim describes a highly positive, seamless experience, with strong alignment
on the brief, effective candidate management, and a successful outcome.
What Went Well
whatWentWell: Tim reported a consistently strong end-to-end experience throughout the search process. The team was described as easy to work with and highly aligned to the organisation's needs: "They absolutely understood the brief, really fully targeted exactly the right people, put a great long list together, managed the candidates really, really well."

Communication and accessibility were highlighted positively: "We had one scheduled weekly call throughout the process... and they were always available for other queries, more ad hoc stuff." The search outcome met expectations fully: "Oh, 100%.
Absolutely. Thoroughly enjoyed working with them."

Administrative and logistical support was noted as a particular strength: "Their admin support was excellent... all the logistical arrangements for the interviews and lunches and all the rest of it... it was just first class, all the way through." Challenges/ Pain Points
challengesPainPoints: No material challenges or pain points were raised during the interview. Tim explicitly noted the absence of issues: "It was one of the most seamless processes I've ever been through. No, there isn't a lot."

Gaps Identified (raised by Tim) No gaps were explicitly identified by Tim in relation to the search engagement. While Tim noted that broader consulting support may require greater organisational scale, this was framed as contextual rather than a shortcoming: "I think we'd need a bit more scale before we went to somebody of Korn Ferry size to do other work like that." Key Themes
keyThemes: Strong relationship and trust-based working model. Tim emphasised the importance of comfort, trust, and ease of working with the search team over an extended period: "You spend a lot of time working with the search... it's about how comfortable you feel with them."

Clear understanding of organisational context. Korn Ferry was perceived as quickly grasping the distinct nature of the organisation and tailoring the search accordingly: "They understood that we are a membership organisation that lobbies on behalf of our members... they had the right people in the room."

Effective use of assessment tools. Psychometric assessment tools were viewed as a meaningful value add and are intended to be used beyond hiring: "We use their psychometric tools for assessment, and they were very, very good.". "It will be used for a development plan, yeah, absolutely."

High-quality consulting capability beyond search (when used). Past experiences with assessment interpretation and remuneration consulting were described positively: "The psychologists... were absolutely first class... she did it brilliantly, absolutely, really clearly." Actions & Recommendations
actionsRecommendations: Continue consistent, structured communication. Maintain the established cadence of regular check-ins and high accessibility, which Tim described as effective and reassuring.
Sustain strong contextual briefing at the outset. Continue investing time early in assignments to ensure deep understanding of organisational nuance, which supported accurate targeting of candidates.

Maintain integration between assessment and development. Where assessment tools are used, continue to position them as inputs into post-hire development planning, reflecting how Tim intends to apply them. Additional Insight
additionalInsight:
Tim highlighted that senior leadership capability, particularly outward-
facing credibility, is a growing priority for the organisation following
the CEO appointment: “The most important thing for us is that our outward
facing activities are done by really high-quality people.”
